sections.1_story: Imagine folding a paper and making several cuts. When you unfold it, the cuts create a beautiful, symmetrical pattern. In exams, paper cutting questions test your ability to mentally visualize the final pattern after a series of folds and cuts.
2_definitions: ğŸ’¡ Paper Cutting: The process of folding paper and making cuts, then unfolding to reveal a pattern.
ğŸ’¡ Symmetry: The balanced arrangement of shapes or patterns on both sides of a fold.
ğŸ’¡ Crease: The line formed by folding the paper.
ğŸ’¡ Unfolding: Opening the paper to see the full pattern.
ğŸ’¡ Cut Pattern: The shape or mark made while the paper is folded.
ğŸ’¡ Overlay: The superimposed pattern after unfolding.
ğŸ’¡ Reflection: The process of flipping the pattern across the fold.
ğŸ’¡ Axis of Fold: The line along which the paper is folded.
ğŸ’¡ Multiple Folds: Folding the paper more than once to increase pattern complexity.
ğŸ’¡ Central Cut: A cut made at the center of the folded paper.
3_formula_bank: ğŸ§® 1. Number of images = 2^number of folds (if all folds are perpendicular).
ğŸ§® 2. A cut at distance 'd' from the fold appears at the same distance on the other side after unfolding.
ğŸ§® 3. For n folds, maximum images = 2^n.
ğŸ§® 4. Central cuts appear at the center after unfolding.
ğŸ§® 5. Edge cuts appear on both edges after unfolding.
ğŸ§® 6. Diagonal folds create diagonal symmetry.
ğŸ§® 7. For square paper, folds along diagonals create fourfold symmetry.
ğŸ§® 8. For rectangular paper, vertical/horizontal folds create twofold symmetry.
ğŸ§® 9. If a cut is on the fold, it appears only once after unfolding.
ğŸ§® 10. The more the folds, the more complex the pattern.
ğŸ§® 11. If a fold is not perfect, the symmetry is imperfect.
ğŸ§® 12. Patterns are always mirrored across the fold axis.
ğŸ§® 13. For odd number of folds, the center line is unique.
ğŸ§® 14. For even number of folds, the pattern is balanced.
ğŸ§® 15. The position of the cut determines the final pattern.
ğŸ§® 16. If a cut is made at the intersection of folds, it appears at all symmetrical positions.
ğŸ§® 17. The number of unique patterns increases with the number of folds.
ğŸ§® 18. For circular paper, radial folds create radial symmetry.
ğŸ§® 19. Each additional fold doubles the number of images.
ğŸ§® 20. The complexity of the pattern increases exponentially with folds.
4_micro_examples: Fold once, cut a triangle at the edge. Unfold: 2 triangles.
Fold twice, cut a circle at the corner. Unfold: 4 circles.
Fold once, cut a square at the center. Unfold: 1 square at center.
Fold diagonally, cut a star at the edge. Unfold: 2 stars diagonally.
Fold vertically, cut a half-moon at the edge. Unfold: 2 half-moons.
Fold twice, cut a heart at the edge. Unfold: 4 hearts.
Fold once, cut a diamond at the fold. Unfold: 1 diamond at center.
Fold horizontally, cut a rectangle at the edge. Unfold: 2 rectangles.
Fold twice, cut a triangle at the intersection. Unfold: 4 triangles.
Fold once, cut a circle at the edge. Unfold: 2 circles.

5_exam_examples.problem: A square paper is folded once vertically and a triangle is cut at the right edge. How many triangles will appear after unfolding?
solution_steps: Folding vertically creates a mirror axis.
Cutting a triangle at the right edge means its image will appear at the left edge after unfolding.

5_exam_examples.problem: A rectangular paper is folded twice (vertically and horizontally) and a circle is cut at one corner. How many circles will appear after unfolding?
solution_steps: Each fold doubles the number of images.

5_exam_examples.problem: A paper is folded diagonally and a square is cut at the fold. Where will the square appear after unfolding?
solution_steps: A cut at the fold appears at the center after unfolding.
So, the square will be at the center.

5_exam_examples.problem: A paper is folded once and a star is cut at the edge. How many stars will appear after unfolding?
A square paper is folded twice and a heart is cut at the intersection of folds. How many hearts will appear after unfolding?
solution_steps: A cut at the intersection appears at all 4 symmetrical positions.
